Perhaps the “however big you think you are” concept derived from that.

Sexy Sadie is Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, as George Harrison explains:

John had a song he had started to write which he was singing: ‘Maharishi, what have you done?’ and I said, ‘You can’t say that, it’s ridiculous.’ I came up with the title of Sexy Sadie and John changed ‘Maharishi’ to ‘Sexy Sadie’.

These lines seem to be modeled after Smokey Robinson & the Miracles' “I’ve Been Good To You”, which begins:

Look what you’ve done
You made a fool of everyone

There’s some irony in the fact that “Fool on the Hill”, released about a year prior, was about Maharishi being perceived as a “fool” but actually being wise. Now Lennon is saying the “fool” made a “fool of everyone”.

Convicted serial killer Charles Manson is known to be obsessed with the Beatles, and particularly with the song Helter Skelter, also from this album. Susan Atkins, on of his “family” members was nicknamed Sexy Sadie.



Listening to the song after the fact makes this line especially ironic – even though the song is unrelated –  as Atkins was incarcerated for life for participating in the Manson family murders.

Sexy Sadie, you broke the rules
 You laid it down for all to see

 Sexy Sadie, oh, you broke the rules

This song is a subtle critique of the Maharishi. However, its title reflects a play on the double meaning of several terms. “Sexy Sadie” is easily imagined as a woman who “breaks the rules” and undresses “for all to see.”

In the context of the Maharishi, those lyrics fit him as well. In 1970, John told Rolling Stone:

That’s about the Maharishi, yes. I copped out and I wouldn’t write ‘Maharishi, what have you done? You made a fool of everyone.’ But now it can be told, Fab Listeners.
